Shortly after the Amazon Appstore launch, the [[International Game Developers Association]] published an open letter expressing concerns that were primarily aimed at Amazon's distribution terms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://igdaboard.wordpress.com/2011/04/14/important-advisory-about-amazon%E2%80%99s-appstore-distribution-terms-2/ |title=Important Advisory about Amazonâs Appstore Distribution Terms |publisher=[[International Game Developers Association]] |accessdate=2011-05-14|quote=''We are not aware of any other retailer having a formal policy of paying a supplier just 20% of the supplierâs minimum list price without the supplierâs permission.(...)If you ever conduct even a temporary price promotion in another market, you must permanently lower your list price in Amazonâs market''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/appsblog/2011/apr/14/amazon-android-appstore-igda |title=IGDA warns Android game developers about Amazon's Appstore terms|publisher=[[guardian.co.uk]] |date=2011-04-14 |accessdate=2011-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/34108/IGDA_Outlines_Significant_Concerns_Over_Amazon_Appstore_Terms.php |title=IGDA Outlines 'Significant Concerns' Over Amazon Appstore Terms|publisher=[[Gamasutra]] |date=2011-04-14 |accessdate=2011-05-14}}</ref> The main gripes about the conditions were that Appstore terms force developers to permanently lower their AppStore prices if ever they do promotions on other stores, and that Amazon could choose to lower the price of an application while deciding to reduce the developers share without having to ask permission.
